publisher: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

funder.name: Gouvernement du Canada | Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada

abstract:
<jats:title>Significance</jats:title>
          <jats:p>Our work challenges the existing paradigm that marine Arctic ecosystems are depauperate extensions of southerly (temperate) communities established in the wake of recent glaciation, fundamentally changing how these systems should be viewed and interpreted. We forward hypotheses regarding the history of Arctic marine systems, particularly with regards to endemism being an integral feature of Arctic biomes, and present a firm framework for future evolutionary research in this system typically viewed as “ecologically immature.”</jats:p>
title: Unique biodiversity in Arctic marine forests is shaped by diverse recolonization pathways and far northern glacial refugia
